Sentence_location: Abstract: Allozyme electrophoresis was used to assess genetic variability and differentiation in 22 populations of Gressittacantha terranova Wise (Hexapoda, Collembola) from a coastal area of Victoria Land between the Mariner Glacier and the Nansen Ice Sheet.

Sentence_location: Genetic differentiation reflects the geographic arrangement of the populations, suggesting that the glaciers are effective barriers to gene flow, and that the patchy distribution of collembolan species in Antarctica has the potential to induce, in the long term, microspeciation processes.

Sentence_location: Received 23 January 2001, accepted 2 May 2001 Key words: allozyme electrophoresis, gene flow, geographic differentiation, genetic distance, heterozygosity, speciation Introduction Gressittacantha terranova Wise, 1967 (Hexapoda, Collembola, Isotomidae) is endemic to Victoria Land, and is one of only eleven species of Collembola reported from Eastern (=Continental) Antarctica (Greenslade 1995).

Sentence_location: Abstract: Allozyme electrophoresis was used to assess genetic variability and differentiation in 22 populations of Gressittacantha terranova Wise (Hexapoda, Collembola) from a coastal area of Victoria Land between the Mariner Glacier and the Nansen Ice Sheet.

Sentence_location: Genetic differentiation reflects the geographic arrangement of the populations, suggesting that the glaciers are effective barriers to gene flow, and that the patchy distribution of collembolan species in Antarctica has the potential to induce, in the long term, microspeciation processes.

Sentence_location: Received 23 January 2001, accepted 2 May 2001 Key words: allozyme electrophoresis, gene flow, geographic differentiation, genetic distance, heterozygosity, speciation Introduction Gressittacantha terranova Wise, 1967 (Hexapoda, Collembola, Isotomidae) is endemic to Victoria Land, and is one of only eleven species of Collembola reported from Eastern (=Continental) Antarctica (Greenslade 1995).

Sentence_location: Gressittacantha terranova is the dominant species between the Mariner Glacier (73°20'S) and the Nansen Ice Sheet (74°55'S) (Fig. 1) where it usually outnumbers the sympatric species Friesea grisea (Schaffer, 1891)

Sentence_location: Abstract: Allozyme electrophoresis was used to assess genetic variability and differentiation in 22 populations of Gressittacantha terranova Wise (Hexapoda, Collembola) from a coastal area of Victoria Land between the Mariner Glacier and the Nansen Ice Sheet.

Sentence_location: Genetic differentiation reflects the geographic arrangement of the populations, suggesting that the glaciers are effective barriers to gene flow, and that the patchy distribution of collembolan species in Antarctica has the potential to induce, in the long term, microspeciation processes.

Sentence_species: Noempirical estimates of populations size are currently available for G. terranova, though direct observations (up to 200-300 specimens concentrated under a single stone) and data collected for other collembolan species (Kennedy 1999), suggest that populations are quite large (several thousands of specimens), possibly contributing to preventing genetic drift from leading to allelic fixation and/or loss.
Sentence_location: Antarctic Science 13 (3): 246-254 (2001) © Antarctic Science Ltd Printed in the United Kingdom High levels of genetic variability and population differentiation in Gressittacantha terranova (Collembola, Hexapoda) from Victoria Land, Antarctica PIETRO PAOLO FANCIULLI, DOMENICO SUMMA, ROMANO DALLAI and FRANCESCO FRATI*

Sentence_species: Noempirical estimates of populations size are currently available for G. terranova, though direct observations (up to 200-300 specimens concentrated under a single stone) and data collected for other collembolan species (Kennedy 1999), suggest that populations are quite large (several thousands of specimens), possibly contributing to preventing genetic drift from leading to allelic fixation and/or loss.
Sentence_location: Abstract: Allozyme electrophoresis was used to assess genetic variability and differentiation in 22 populations of Gressittacantha terranova Wise (Hexapoda, Collembola) from a coastal area of Victoria Land between the Mariner Glacier and the Nansen Ice Sheet.

Sentence_species: Noempirical estimates of populations size are currently available for G. terranova, though direct observations (up to 200-300 specimens concentrated under a single stone) and data collected for other collembolan species (Kennedy 1999), suggest that populations are quite large (several thousands of specimens), possibly contributing to preventing genetic drift from leading to allelic fixation and/or loss.
Sentence_location: Genetic differentiation reflects the geographic arrangement of the populations, suggesting that the glaciers are effective barriers to gene flow, and that the patchy distribution of collembolan species in Antarctica has the potential to induce, in the long term, microspeciation processes.

Sentence_location: Received 23 January 2001, accepted 2 May 2001 Key words: allozyme electrophoresis, gene flow, geographic differentiation, genetic distance, heterozygosity, speciation Introduction Gressittacantha terranova Wise, 1967 (Hexapoda, Collembola, Isotomidae) is endemic to Victoria Land, and is one of only eleven species of Collembola reported from Eastern (=Continental) Antarctica (Greenslade 1995).

Sentence_location: Abstract: Allozyme electrophoresis was used to assess genetic variability and differentiation in 22 populations of Gressittacantha terranova Wise (Hexapoda, Collembola) from a coastal area of Victoria Land between the Mariner Glacier and the Nansen Ice Sheet.

Sentence_species: Gaertn., Meyer et Scherb. and Hennediella heimii (Hedw.)
Sentence_location: Genetic differentiation reflects the geographic arrangement of the populations, suggesting that the glaciers are effective barriers to gene flow, and that the patchy distribution of collembolan species in Antarctica has the potential to induce, in the long term, microspeciation processes.

Sentence_species: Gaertn., Meyer et Scherb. and Hennediella heimii (Hedw.)
Sentence_location: Received 23 January 2001, accepted 2 May 2001 Key words: allozyme electrophoresis, gene flow, geographic differentiation, genetic distance, heterozygosity, speciation Introduction Gressittacantha terranova Wise, 1967 (Hexapoda, Collembola, Isotomidae) is endemic to Victoria Land, and is one of only eleven species of Collembola reported from Eastern (=Continental) Antarctica (Greenslade 1995).

Sentence_location: The development of collembolan communities in Antarctica, as with all Antarctic soil arthropods (Kennedy 1993, Block 1994), is largely dependent upon the availability of free water, the presence of some vegetation, a direct or indirect food source (Kennedy 1999), and stones which provide shelter 246 from dehydrating winds (Frati et al. 1997).

Sentence_location: Received 23 January 2001, accepted 2 May 2001 Key words: allozyme electrophoresis, gene flow, geographic differentiation, genetic distance, heterozygosity, speciation Introduction Gressittacantha terranova Wise, 1967 (Hexapoda, Collembola, Isotomidae) is endemic to Victoria Land, and is one of only eleven species of Collembola reported from Eastern (=Continental) Antarctica (Greenslade 1995).
